awd_titl_txt: SCC: I4all (Interests for All): A Smart Socio-Technical Infrastructure to Identify, Cultivate, and Sustain Youth STEAM Interests in a Diverse Midsized American City
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a Smart and Connected Communities award. The community is part of Evanston, Illinois and is composed of the lead partners described below:

- EvanSTEM which is a in-school/out of school time (OST) program to improve access and engagement for students in Evanston who have underperformed or been underrepresented in STEM.

- McGaw YMCA which consists of 12,000 families serving 20,000 individuals and supporting technology and makerspace activities (MetaMedia) in a safe community atmosphere.

- Office of Community Education Partnerships (OCEP) at Northwestern University which provides support for the university and community to collaborate on research, teaching, and service initiatives. 

This partnership will develop a new approach to learning enagement through the STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics) interests of all young people in Evanston. This project is entitled Interests for All (I4All) and builds upon existing research results of the two Principal Investigators (PIs) and previous partnerships between the lead partners (EvanSTEM and MetaMedia had OCEP as a founding partner). I4All also brings together Evanston school districts, OST prividers, the city, and Evanston's Northwestern University as participants.
  
In particular the project builds on PI Pinkard's Cities of Learning project and co-PI Stevens' FUSE Studios project. Both of these projects have explicit goals to broaden participation in STEAM pursuits, a goal that is significantly advanced through I4All. In this project, I4All infrastructure will be evaluated using quantitative metrics that will tell the researchers whether and to what degree Evanston youth are finding and developing their STEAM interests and whether the I4All infrastructure supports a significantly more equitable distribution of opportunities to youth. The researchers will also conduct in depth qualitative case studies of youth interest development. These longitudinal studies will complement the quantitative metrics of participation and give measures that will be used in informing changes in I4All as part of the PIs Design Based Implementation Research approach. The artifacts produced in I4All include FUSE studio projects, software infrastructure to guide the students through OST and in-school activities and to provide to the  students actionable information as to logistics for participation in I4All activities, and data that will be available to all stakeholders to evaluate the effectiveness of I4All. Additionally, this research has the potential to provide for scaling this model to different communities, leveraging the OST network in one community to begin to offer professional development more widely throughout the school districts and as an exemplar for other districts. These research results could also affect strategies and policies created by local school officials and community organizations regarding how to work together to create local learning environments to create an ecosystem where formal and informal learning spaces support and reinforce STEAM knowledge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project focused on building and refining L3, an enterprise platform, as a socio-technical infrastructure to better understand hyperlocal out-of-school technology, engineering, and arts (TEA) opportunities and participation patterns for middle school youth in Evanston School District 65 and to use that understanding to (re)allocate resources to support youth interest development and learning. This work provides a national model for ensuring that youth have equitable opportunities and expectations for participation, giving agency in decision-making to community stakeholders, families, and youth, including interpretation of and response to systematically documented data about out-of-school learning.

While the global pandemic negatively impacted our team?s ability to conduct interviews with youth and families, our efforts to develop geospatial representations of learning opportunities were positively impacted; hence our efforts shifted during the life of the grant life to focus more on four interconnected strands of work: 

  • Operationalize the opportunity landscape concept by creating a core set of interactive dashboards (including GIS representations) through cycles of community feedback and interpretation through the hosting of stakeholder meetings at different levels.
  •  Establishing a process for documenting a community?s existing resources (places, spaces, providers, and policies) to ensure stakeholder conversations embed historical and current understanding of a community. 
  •  Establishing a data warehouse to power historical and current opportunity landscape dashboards and academic research in learning infrastructure, informal learning opportunities, barriers to participation, and learning pathways.
  •  Investigating, analyzing, and mapping youth and mentors? interests
  • Developing a mentor training initiative, STEAMbassadors, to address the critical shortage of a hyperlocal workforce to support youth in underrepresented communities in STEAM exploration and play during the winter and summer academic breaks.

Throughout this grant, our work has resulted in the following key outcomes and achievements:

  • Real-time interactive dashboards of Evanston and Chicago OST opportunity landscape that detailed the impact of COVID on access to informal learning resources by visualizing changes in locations and providers during the years 2018-2021. Our maps and associated organizational surveys facilitated mayoral efforts to provide resources targeted at supporting organizational and community resilience. 
  • 275 STEAMbassadors (representing Chicago city colleges and young adults who have grown up in the Chicago area) trained to lead summer STEAM camps online and in person at over 35 Chicago and Evanston civic-learning sites providing 1,800 program spots. Camps were strategically placed in communities identified through analysis of opportunity landscape data as locations needing additional OST opportunities for youth.
  • The launch of My CHI, My Future (MCMF) in the fall of 2019 was powered by the L3 platform. MCMF, a mayoral-led initiative, provides research access to a citywide real-time understanding of OST learning and leisure opportunities for youth. Through this program, we have provided access to the data through the Chicago city data portal. 
  • Release of the L3 platform for use by non-study cities for reimagining their opportunity landscapes. This grant supported the designed and implemented enhancements to L3, including the community and parent portals, which are essential for working with families and communities to plan their STEAM engagement intentionally.
  • Launch of a study to understand the impact of STEAMbassador participation on mentors learning, interest, and identity development through Interviews, surveys, weblogs, and weekly and end-of-program reflection data. 

This project's products for operationalizing OST learning ecosystems: the opportunity landscape framework, the L3 technology platform, data warehouse, and data-infused community engagement activity structures a national exemplar of how to create and implement infrastructures and social practices that support and make visible learning across in and out-of-school contexts while providing stakeholders access to both the data and collaboration tools to engage in needed conversation.

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2022
Modified by: Nichole Pinkard

This collaborative project focused on building and refining L3, an enterprise platform, as a socio-technical infrastructure to better understand hyperlocal out-of-school technology, engineering, and arts (TEA) opportunities and participation patterns for middle school youth in Evanston School District 65 and to use that understanding to (re)allocate resources to support youth interest development and learning. This work provides a national model for ensuring that youth have equitable opportunities and expectations for participation, giving agency in decision-making to community stakeholders, families, and youth, including interpretation of and response to systematically documented data about out-of-school learning.

While the global pandemic negatively impacted our team?s ability to conduct interviews with youth and families, our efforts to develop geospatial representations of learning opportunities were positively impacted; hence our efforts shifted during the life of the grant life to focus more on four interconnected strands of work: 

Operationalize the opportunity landscape concept by creating a core set of interactive dashboards (including GIS representations) through cycles of community feedback and interpretation through the hosting of stakeholder meetings at different levels.
 Establishing a process for documenting a community?s existing resources (places, spaces, providers, and policies) to ensure stakeholder conversations embed historical and current understanding of a community. 
 Establishing a data warehouse to power historical and current opportunity landscape dashboards and academic research in learning infrastructure, informal learning opportunities, barriers to participation, and learning pathways.

Developing a mentor training initiative, STEAMbassadors, to address the critical shortage of a hyperlocal workforce to support youth in underrepresented communities in STEAM exploration and play during the winter and summer academic breaks.


Throughout this grant, our work has resulted in the following key outcomes and achievements:

Real-time interactive dashboards of Evanston and Chicago OST opportunity landscape that detailed the impact of COVID on access to informal learning resources by visualizing changes in locations and providers during the years 2018-2021. Our maps and associated organizational surveys facilitated mayoral efforts to provide resources targeted at supporting organizational and community resilience. 
275 STEAMbassadors (representing Chicago city colleges and young adults who have grown up in the Chicago area) trained to lead summer STEAM camps online and in person at over 35 Chicago and Evanston civic-learning sites providing 1,800 program spots. Camps were strategically placed in communities identified through analysis of opportunity landscape data as locations needing additional OST opportunities for youth.
The launch of My CHI, My Future (MCMF) in the fall of 2019 was powered by the L3 platform. MCMF, a mayoral-led initiative, provides research access to a citywide real-time understanding of OST learning and leisure opportunities for youth. Through this program, we have provided access to the data through the Chicago city data portal. 
Release of the L3 platform for use by non-study cities for reimagining their opportunity landscapes. This grant supported the designed and implemented enhancements to L3, including the community and parent portals, which are essential for working with families and communities to plan their STEAM engagement intentionally.
Launch of a study to understand the impact of STEAMbassador participation on mentors learning, interest, and identity development through Interviews, surveys, weblogs, and weekly and end-of-program reflection data. 


This project's products for operationalizing OST learning ecosystems: the opportunity landscape framework, the L3 technology platform, data warehouse, and data-infused community engagement activity structures a national exemplar of how to create and implement infrastructures and social practices that support and make visible learning across in and out-of-school contexts while providing stakeholders access to both the data and collaboration tools to engage in needed conversation.
